result.content:
## Markdown cell

A `Markdown` cell is used to add information. There are many resources on the internet about how to write Markdown, such as [this one](https://culturedcode.com/things/support/articles/4651820/).

You can do links, paragraphs, styles, titles even tables!

| example table | views | likes |
|:---:|---|---|
| option 1 | 126 | 9 |
| option 2 | 80 | 9 |

## Text

A text question prompts the user for textual information

## Checkbox

Checkboxes present the user with some options to choose.

result.title: Please select all the options that apply
result.description: We also have some options to select ALL or None.

result.content:
## Radio

Radio questions present the user with options, but the user can only select one.

result.title: Pick the option that best applies

result.content:
## Number

Number questions ask about a quantity

result.title: Please select how many
result.description: you also can set a min and max

result.content:
## Number Matrix

The number matrix lets the user type in many numbers in a table. You can preset the rows or ask the user to add their own.

result.title: Please add in all the numbers you have on record

result.content:
## File

Files let the user upload files into the system

## Summary

A summary is not a question, it is used to visualize the results of questions graphically.

In order for a summary to work, it needs to be connected to scored questions, it will sum the input questions values.

## Aggregate

Aggregates is not a question, it visualizes the results of other questions (or summaries). Aggregate computes the mean of it's input scores, whereas summary sums them.

# Scoring with Connections

When questions are scored (commonly checkbox or radio), you can connect them to summary or aggregates to provide visual feedback.

summaries add all connected scores questions up. Two cells are connected if they are a member of the same group

Try the demoFiller [here](https://observablehq.com/@categorise/opensurvey?username=demoResponder#FnMcjZO1pn1uqmMh|logic)

result.title: How much score do you want?

result.content:
# Visibility with Connections

You can use connections between cells to control visibility. Give cells in connection group the roles *ifno*, *ifyes* to toggle their visibility based on the value in a *yesnomaybe*, *yes* or *no* cell role.

result.title: this cell has the yesnomaybe role and it drives the visibility of the other cells below it

result.content: This will appear if the other question is answered with yes becuase it has the role ifyes
This will appear if the question is anwered no, and has the role ifno
